articles.headline: Surprise Loss at Wachovia Stirs Profit-Season Unease
articles.snippet: The red ink at Wachovia, the country’s fourth-largest bank, signals that the pain for the financial industry is far from over.
articles.abstract: The red ink at Wachovia, the country’s fourth-largest bank, signals that the pain for the financial industry is far from over.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Wachovia Corporation kicked off what is expected to be a grim earnings season for the nation’s banks on Monday, stunning Wall Street with an unexpected loss.

articles.headline: Facing Decline, an Effort to Market the Priesthood
articles.snippet: Gone are the days when several hundred men at a time studied to be ordained as priests for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. Today, only 22 are enrolled.
articles.abstract: Gone are the days when several hundred men at a time studied to be ordained as priests for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. Today, only 22 are enrolled.
articles.lead_paragraph: The banners hanging in the main corridor of St. Joseph’s Seminary in Yonkers declare, “Through Faith We Grow.” The class portraits that line that very same corridor tell the opposite tale. Half a century after the halcyon days when several hundred men at a time studied to be ordained as priests for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, only 22 are enrolled.

articles.headline: Economy Ailing, Frustrated Italy Picks Berlusconi
articles.snippet: The billionaire Silvio Berlusconi’s center-right coalition won a convincing majority in both houses of Parliament.
articles.abstract: The billionaire Silvio Berlusconi’s center-right coalition won a convincing majority in both houses of Parliament.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME  Silvio Berlusconi, the idiosyncratic billionaire who already dominates much of Italy’s public life, snatched back political power in elections that ended Monday, heading a center-right coalition certain to make him prime minister for a third term.

articles.headline: Bridging the Gap, the Sequel
articles.snippet: Only 350 miles separate the two California business cultures, but executives are once more trying to bridge the gap between technology and entertainment.
articles.abstract: Only 350 miles separate the two California business cultures, but executives are once more trying to bridge the gap between technology and entertainment.
articles.lead_paragraph: A story that Daniel Scheinman, a senior vice president at Cisco Systems in San Jose, Calif., likes to tell illustrates the cultural divide between Hollywood and his Silicon Valley.

articles.headline: Delta and Northwest in $3 Billion Deal
articles.snippet: The merger deal will create the world’s biggest airline and may trigger other airlines to pursue mergers of their own.
articles.abstract: The merger deal will create the world’s biggest airline and may trigger other airlines to pursue mergers of their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines agreed to merge late Monday, in a $3.1 billion deal that would create the world’s biggest airline and could prompt other airlines to pursue mergers of their own.
articles.byline: By Jeff Bailey and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Retailing Chains Caught in a Wave of Bankruptcies
articles.snippet: A consumer spending slump and tightening credit markets are prompting thousands of store closings.
articles.abstract: A consumer spending slump and tightening credit markets are prompting thousands of store closings.
articles.lead_paragraph: The consumer spending slump and tightening credit markets are unleashing a widening wave of bankruptcies in American retailing, prompting thousands of store closings that are expected to remake suburban malls and downtown shopping districts across the country.

articles.headline: Wall Streeter Converts to a Fan of Regulation
articles.snippet: Robert K. Steel’s apparent conversion to the merits of regulation illustrates how the laissez-faire bones of the Bush administration have been rattled by the trauma of the credit crisis.
articles.abstract: Robert K. Steel’s apparent conversion to the merits of regulation illustrates how the laissez-faire bones of the Bush administration have been rattled by the trauma of the credit crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert K. Steel leans forward, speaking in a rapid, excitable burst about the powers that a superregulator might wield over Wall Street one day.

articles.headline: Fuel Choices, Food Crises and Finger-Pointing
articles.snippet: Biofuels are fast becoming a new flash point in global diplomacy, putting pressure on Western politicians.
articles.abstract: Biofuels are fast becoming a new flash point in global diplomacy, putting pressure on Western politicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: The idea of turning farms into fuel plants seemed, for a time, like one of the answers to high global oil prices and supply worries. That strategy seemed to reach a high point last year when Congress mandated a fivefold increase in the use of biofuels.

articles.headline: Faith in Spotlight, Candidates Battle for Catholic Votes
articles.snippet: Democrats, who lost among Catholics in the 2004 presidential election, are trying to woo them back.
articles.abstract: Democrats, who lost among Catholics in the 2004 presidential election, are trying to woo them back.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Many years have passed since the Democratic Party was as much a part of American Catholic identity as weekly Mass and parochial school. But it still came as a shock to many Democrats to lose the Catholic vote, a key group in must-win states like Ohio, in the 2004 presidential election.

articles.headline: A Recluse Lifts the Veil a Little
articles.snippet: Stephen A. Feinberg, the reclusive founder of Cerberus Capital Management and the money man some hope will save Detroit, is no Gordon Gekko.
articles.abstract: Stephen A. Feinberg, the reclusive founder of Cerberus Capital Management and the money man some hope will save Detroit, is no Gordon Gekko.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephen A. Feinberg, the money man some hope will save Detroit, seemed almost apologetic. “I don’t blame anyone who doesn’t know me from thinking a lot of things,” said Mr. Feinberg, the reclusive founder of Cerberus Capital Management, the big buyout firm.

articles.headline: At State Level, More Attempts to Limit Guns
articles.snippet: The efforts to pass new restrictions on guns come after nearly a decade in which gun advocates have dominated.
articles.abstract: The efforts to pass new restrictions on guns come after nearly a decade in which gun advocates have dominated.
articles.lead_paragraph: State lawmakers across the country are ramping up efforts to pass new restrictions on guns, following nearly a decade in which state legislative efforts have been dominated by gun advocates.
